answer:

Length = 37.5cm ÷ 3 = 12.5 cm.

question:
(a) Draw a sketch map of Africa. On the map, show and name the
(i) River Nile; (ii) River Niger; (iii) River Orange (iv) River Zambezi

(b) Describe four characteristics of African rivers

(c) Highlight three uses of African rivers
answer:
(b) Characteristics of African Rivers

(a) Most of the rivers are characterised by rapids, cataracts and waterfalls

(b) Most of them are seasonal in nature. They only flow during the rainy season

(c) Most of the rivers are shallow

(d) Most African rivers are short in length and fast flowing

(e) There is seasonal fluctuation in the volume of water

(f) Some rivers have weeds / floating vegetation

(g) Many African rivers contain debris or sediments such as leave, mud, etc.

(h) Most African rivers change their colour especially during the rainy season mainly because of the sediments they carry during this time.

(c) Uses of African rivers
(1) For domestic purpose
(2) For industrial purpose
(3) For tourism
(4) For irrigation e.g Nile
(5) Generation of hydro-electric power
(6) Employment / fishing
(7) For transportation and development of ports
(8) Alluvial soils for agriculture
(9) Source of proteinous food
(10) Presence of minerals such as gold, diamond
(11) Used as natural / political boundaries.

question:
(a) Draw an outline map of Africa. On the map, show and name
(i) one area that receives rainfall in winter;
(ii) the dominant air masses over Africa in July;
(iii) the position of the ITCZ in July

(b) Explain the effects of altitude on the climate of Africa.
answer:
(b) Effects of latitude on the climate of Africa
(a) Temperature decreases with altitude at an average rate of 6.5°C for approximately 1000m of vertical ascent

(b) High altitude area experience high amount of rainfall because of orographic effect

(c) In high altitude areas like Jos, there is little air to distribute the heat, hence cooler climate

(d) High altitude areas have less dust and water vapour and so allow the heat to escape rapidly

(e) On the windward side, rainfall is higher than the surrounding areas whereas on the leeward side, the rainfall is either scanty or low

(f) Since the atmosphere is heated by conduction, area close to the earth's surface are thus warmer

(g) Nairobi and Mombasa, for instance, are almost on the same latitude but Nairobi in a higher latitude (1675m) has lower mean annual temperature than Mombasa (1600m)
